DABBAGH and BURTRON H. DAVIS Kentucky Energy Cabinet Laboratory, P.O. Box 13015, Lexington, KY 40512 (U.S.A.) (Received May 19, 1987; accepted February 4, 1988) Alkene distribution from alcohol dehydration may be classified according to: (a) Saytzeff elimination, where the dominant products are those that correspond to the most stable products, and (b) Hofmann elimina- tion, where the major product is the less stable alkene. From the viewpoint of catalysis the products from Hofmann elimination are of special interest, since they should be determined by the properties of the catalyst. The selectivity for products from elimination reaction are frequently explained on the basis of progress along the reaction coordinate pathway. Thus, for those reactions where the dominant product is the most stable alkene, the transition state is considered to be attained late in the progress along the reaction coordinate, so that the transition state is 'product-like'. For dehydration of 2-ols, 2-alkene is usually the most stable product. In these cases where the dominant dehydration product is 2-alkene, the acti- vated complex would be product-like, wherein the C OH bond would be nearly, or completely, broken. Thus, in the extreme this reaction pathway would be a typical E-l carbonium ion mechanism (as illustrated in Scheme 1 for a strong protonic acid). Thus, very acidic catalysts, such as zeolites and amorphous silica-alumina, are believed to follow such a mechanism [1]. At the other extreme is a typical E-2 carbanion ion mechanism (see Scheme 1), where the acidity of the protons at the j3-position to the OH group of the alcohol determines the alkene selectivity. Thus, elimination of water from a 2-ol by an E-2-like mechanism should produce Hofmann products (a-olefins, 1-alkenes) while an E-l-like mechanism should provide Saytzeff products (ss-olefins, 2-alkenes). It was of special interest when Lundeen and van Hoozer [2, 3] dis- covered that the use of thoria, and several similar oxides, as catalysts resulted in a decided selectivity for the formation of the Hofmann product (1-alkene) from the dehydration of 2-alcohols. This Hofmann selectivity has been verified by a number of investigations, for example [4 - 8]. Elimination by pyrolysis of HBr from 2-bromo-2,4,4-trimethylpen- tane was of special interest, since the initial results appeared to violate the Saytzeff rule [10] for elimination. However, it was soon realized that the rule violation was only apparent, since the 1-alkene (the Hofmann product in most eliminations) was in this case more stable than the 2-alkene [11, 12]. This is a fortunate circumstance, since the alcohol 2,4,4-trimethyl-2- pentanol provides an opportunity to compare elimination reactions over catalysts with reactants where (a) the Saytzeff product is the stable one (2-octanol) and (b) the Saytzeff product is less stable (2,4,4-trimethyl-2- pentanol) than the Hofmann product. Except for alumina, the catalysts were prepared by calcining in air the hydroxide obtained by precipitation from a nitrate solution with ammonia. The alumina was prepared by addition of COz to a potassium aluminate solution [13]. 2,4,4-Trimethyl-2-pentanol was prepared from 4,4-dimethyl-2-pentanone by the addition of methylmagnesium chloride. Alcohol dehydration was effected in a plug flow reactor [6]; the catalyst was pretreated at 400 C in hydrogen flow prior to use. The products were analyzed by GC using 10% OV-1 on a Chromosorb column. The fraction of dehydration and the alkene products depend upon the preparation and pretreatment of the thoria catalyst [8]. It was therefore desirable to verify the selectivity of the thoria used in this study. The selec- tivity of the thoria used can be seen from the data from the conversion of several secondary and tertiary alcohols (Table 1). It is apparent that all of the 2-ols, as well as the two tertiary alcohols, produce 70 - 90% of the less stable Hofmann elimination product. These results conform to, and extend, the earlier data [2-8] for the use of thoria. As important as the Hofmann selectivity is the observation that a variation of the alkyi group R, in the reactant RCHzCHOHCHa, does not alter the amount of Hof mann elimination. A similar observation [14] has been reported for the other metal oxide catalysts used m this study (Table 2). 126 The alkene products from the conversion of 2,4,4-trimethyl-2-pentan- ol are compiled in Table 3. Considering only the 1- and 2-alkene products, the equilibrium composition at these reaction conditions contains approx- imately 82 - 84% of the 1-isomer [11, 12]. The metal oxide catalysts in Table 3 were chosen to cover the range of ~40 - 90% 1-octene in the 1- + 2-octene products from the conversion of 2-octanol [9]. In the cases of thoria and zirconia, it appears that the observed selectivity, with a greater than the equilibrium amount of 1-alkene, agrees with its selectivity for a- olefin product [5 - 8, 16]. However, even in these cases, the enhanced selec- tivity for a-olefin is not much greater than the equilibrium amount, nor could it be. Saytzeff or Hofmann elimination preference is illustrated by the data in Table 2 for 2-octanol dehydration; alumina leads to Saytzeff elimination, while the other three metal oxides follow the Hofmann selec- tivity. If the product stability determined the product selectivity, we should expect a reversal of the selectivity data shown in Table 2, so that in the dehydration of 2,4,4-trimethyl-2-pentanol with alumina the a-olefin would predominate and with the other three metal oxides the ss olefin would be the dominant product. However, the a- vs. ss-olefin selectivity does not show a reversal of the amount of product expected from the above consideration. Rather, it appears that water elimination from 2,4,4-trimethyl-2-pentanol produces the equilibrium, or near equilibrium, o'/ss-olefin distribution. Thus, on the one hand, the results demonstrate that the Hofmann/Saytzeff selec- tivity with this alcohol is not reversed from that obtained with other 2-ols but, on the other hand, the near equilibrium composition of a- and ss-olefins prevents the data from being useful in deciding the mechanism that produces these 2,4,4-trimethylpentenes.
